If the rain is falling straight down to earth and your standing straight up, your surface area contacting rain is your upper head and upper shoulders. last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>1870921
Did you do the math? graf zeppelin ii carried 70 passengers and 40 crew members, and used 65000kg of diesel fuel (so 79000l) for a 16500km range. That's around 479 liters spent every 100 km, or a 6.84 l/100km fuel consumption per passenger - which sounds high compared to current aircraft (2.27 to 3.76 l/100km), but that fails to consider that every passenger had it's own cabin while modern airlines try to cram as many people as possible for a given payload.

Using the 787 as a reference, that can carry a maximum of 440 people for a 57277 kg payload - as the graf zeppelin ii can carry a 37000 kg payload, that would mean that given the same passenger density it would have 284 seats, and consume 1,69 l/100km per passenger. Argue all you want that you can't cram that many people in trips that take days instead of hours, but that still means that 1930's technology beats any new passenger plane in terms of raw fuel efficiency...

Once again, airships have quite a few problems (travel time, construction costs, lack of climb ability, sheer size), but fuel consumption isn't one of them.

Sospension forks usually don't have mounting points at the crown. Only at the bridge. And that's the case for this setup, as you can deduce by the fact that there's a fendere flushed with the wheel, and not with the crown.
I mean, do you really think that i went a long way sizing and buying p-clips, to then attach the rack in between the sprung and the unsprung parts of the fork?

Thet being said, i had to mount the brake levers and the handlebar so that nothing (included my hands) gets crushed when the fork bottoms down.

Anyway, i previously had a 28" city bike with a Suntour suspension fork (it was just a pair of springs, no dumping), and the handling was awful with anything fit inside the front crate.
Whit this thing i can definitely feel thet my fron is loaded in front of the trailing point, but giving that it's a 26" and the fork is an RTS made for MTBs, the stability is like there was nothing in the crate.

28" city bikes are shit for loading crates into them.
But 90s MTBs are not the most nimble thing for doing 30km a day in a city.

Let's be honest, i should buy a touring bike or a touring fork. But i will bever spend more than 300 bucks for a bicycle.

Without looking at Australian rail freight for more than 10 seconds, my impression of it is that it's mostly very long trains with heavy bulk goods. That's practically a no-brainer to put on trains, and even the worst rail freight systems in the world would still get the heavy bulk.
I personally look a lot at how well rail competes with road when I gauge the success of rail freight, because a punctual, reliable and commercially viable rail freight system attracts a lot of goods that otherwise would be shipped by road. The range these airships have compared to the amount of fuel they carry already indicates they were working rather efficiently.>>1862751

If you do the math, you'll also see that at top speed (thus peak inneficiency) the graf zeppelin ii needa 3,56 Mw of power to attain 135 km/h, which amounts to around 78 kn of thrust or 7600 kgf if you assume a propeller efficiency of 80%.

something about the sole being stiff?

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>1869368
skate shoes and bike shoes are pretty much opposites. skate shoes have a lot of padding and a thin, flexible sole for "boardfeel". they can also have reinforced toe area and stiffness/material around the ankle for support. bike shoes don't have as much padding, and have a stiffer sole to support the foot and make better power transfer when pedaling.

>Couldn't you attach the rack to the center hole on the fork? I'm trying to get some front storage solution for my Trek 930 and I'm wondering how I could solve the issue with a rear rack mounted on the front.

Yeah, I could. What I usually use to do that is an old metal reflector bracket. I keep a box of em pulled off bikes for this purpose. They're pretty stout, and they drop to clear the straddle cable. They come with the long fork crown bolt. You can usually bend/drill/hacksaw them to work quite well. Center your holes with a punch first. Bending is easiest with a vice but possible with a big crescent wrench. m5/m6 bolts, nyloc nuts, washers.

It's not really necessary on this though. The rack is a front rack and the way it's designed to mount works quite well. It's relatively stable with 10kg in it. Plus the strut would need to be very long.

You can still run it, A side cars cabs go from side to side, like in OP picture, the controls are on the left, however the motorman can go to the other side too (right behind the "7" bullet)

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>1870134
The cabs are just there to give line of sight, a train can have only one cab and still go the other way.
SLTM has an R17 which should have a half cab at each end iirc.
The current MTA fleet is the NTT trains which are the fancy shitty trains. The R142, R147 and R160.
The old ones are the R62 (OP pic), R46 and R68.
The R62 and R68 have have both full width cabs, and half cabs on each train car.

The R46 on the other hand have A and B cars. A cars have a full width cab on one end and nothing on the other. The B cars have no cabs at all, and are usually married in am A-B-B-A consist.

MTA is retarded and there are a lot of standardized practices, trains are barely if ever moved around, and having them married means you have one less point of failure. Also doesn't help that niggers have been getting into train cabs and fucking over trains.

>>1869870
Do the math...
Let's say you are riding e-bike 2 hours. Legs input power is 105 watts. At 95% mechanical transmission efeciency it's 100 watts at wheel.
Replacing mechanical with electric transmission at 76% efficiency. That 80 watts at wheel with same 105 watts legs input. 20 watts to compensate comes from battery. Over two hours it's 40 wh*h. Single 21700 is about 18 wh*h, so it's 2-3 extra 21700 or 140-210 grams.

They do make it a lot easier to stay in the big ring while climbing, so that somewhat makes up for the annoyance, but round chainrings are definitely not a conspiracy to make you slow.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>1866353
Not exactly. They had some racing heritage, even so this isn't the reason they went under. They had success before and during the bike boom but this made them too comfortable. During the bike boom, the U.S. enjoyed a better selection of racier, lighter bikes from recent import from Europe and Japan, and American customers sort of realized that American bike manufacturers, even if they made bikes that looked like road bikes (Varsity, Continental, Super Sport etc), were about 5-10 years behind in terms of technology especially regarding frame tubing. Boomers will cope and say that they are heavy because they are bomb-proof, but the maybe small drop in durability of the foreign bikes was worth the weight savings. These American "racy" looking bikes were just absolute boat anchors, and even shitty Peugeot gaspipe shitters were lighter. American tastes had changed a little by the end of the bike boom.
Eventually Schwinn realized the changing market but was a little late to react to the change. They pretty much never recovered from this. Eventually they tried to get people back with cheaper and sportier frames made in Taiwan and Japan, but the damage had already been done. Their reputation as low-tech, heavy bikes went with them into the 80s. This foreign manufacture also sort of ruined their image as The American Bicycle Manufacturer. What was the point of the company if half their frames were foreign?This meant that from the 80s on was all an effort to slow down how hard they were falling. It's a shame because they really made some nice stuff in the late 80s/early 90s, especially the Japanese stuff.
TLDR Schwinn got too comfortable from their success from having a monopoly on American sales for decades, and didn't advance their tech fast enough. When they finally had advanced competition from outside America they got left behind and never recovered.

Pre-cast makes more sense for public infrastructure as it reduces the amount of time construction takes. Longer construction times means longer road/rail/whatever closures and higher costs. Pre-fab beams dramatically reduce the time costs but massively increase transport costs. If a beam/column is too big or complex it will be cheaper to fabricate on site. It could also be due to needing a certain level of quality control/assurance. Something like pre-stressing steel reinforcements could be cheaper to do off-site depending on size, dimensions, reinforcements used, etc etc. At the end of the day highway engineers (and civil engineers of today) aren't designers aren't architects and they don't care about what you think of a concrete flyover.

>>1867010
Probably forty or fifty years late. The three-foot tracks disappeared in the late 80s and the cape gauge before that. There was lots of cape gauge in Blekinge to the point it was called "Blekinge Gauge" in Sweden. The last piece of cape gauge in revenue service was a freight line from Karlshamn, closed in '79.
The three-foot lives on as Roslagsbanan, which has dodged many bullets.
